guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • Wax
  • Sand
  • Wick
  • Wax coloring
Tools
  • Fire extinguisher
  • Large bowl
  • Metal pot
  • Something to melt the wax with
  • Thermometer

lines.text: The correct and safest way to melt wax is with a bain-marie, or water bath, because the wax is highly flammable. I chose to use a gas burner because for this kind of candle you need the wax to be very hot in order for the sand to soak in and make a thick outer layer.
lines.text_raw: The correct and safest way to melt wax is with a [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bain-marie|bain-marie], or water bath, because the wax is highly flammable. I chose to use a gas burner because for this kind of candle you need the wax to be very hot in order for the sand to soak in and make a thick outer layer.

lines.text: First we need to make the sand mould. Fill a large container with sand. The sand must be moist in order to hold its shape. Make a hole in the sand and bury an object in order to make the mould.
lines.text_raw: First we need to make the sand mould. Fill a large container with sand. The sand must be moist in order to hold its shape. Make a hole in the sand and bury an object in order to make the mould.

lines.text: Compact the sand around the object, take it out and you are left with this.
lines.text_raw: Compact the sand around the object, take it out and you are left with this.

lines.text: Suspend the wicks over the moulds and you are ready to pour the hot wax.
lines.text_raw: Suspend the wicks over the moulds and you are ready to pour the hot wax.

lines.text: Melt the wax until it comes almost to a boil; about 126 degrees Celsius. If you haven’t got a thermometer, watch the wax carefully and you will see it starting to move as if it is boiling. That’s a good indication that it's time to take it off the fire.
lines.text_raw: Melt the wax until it comes almost to a boil; about 126 degrees Celsius. If you haven’t got a thermometer, watch the wax carefully and you will see it starting to move as if it is boiling. That’s a good indication that it's time to take it off the fire.

lines.text: Never ever leave the hot wax unattended and keep it away from kids and pets. It's best to work outdoors away from flammable items Keep a fire extinguisher close at hand.
lines.text_raw: Never ever leave the hot wax unattended and keep it away from kids and pets. It's best to work outdoors away from flammable items Keep a fire extinguisher close at hand.

lines.text: If the wax should catch fire, DO NOT pour water on it! Turn off the heat and cover the container with a lid in order to deprive it of oxygen.
lines.text_raw: If the wax should catch fire, DO NOT pour water on it! Turn off the heat and cover the container with a lid in order to deprive it of oxygen.

lines.text: Pour the wax in the moulds.
lines.text_raw: Pour the wax in the moulds.

lines.text: You will need to top up the wax after some time because it soaks into the sand and the level will drop.
lines.text_raw: You will need to top up the wax after some time because it soaks into the sand and the level will drop.

lines.text: Once the wax has hardened you can take the candles out and scrape off any loose sand on the outside.
